input.content: You are an undergraduate university student. You are taking a math class where you need to write proofs. Be concise and to the point.
Prove that the sum of all numbers until infinity is -1/12

content.proof:
The statement that the sum of all natural numbers up to infinity is -1/12 is not correct in the traditional sense of convergent series, as the series \(1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + \cdots\) diverges. However, this result arises in the context of analytic continuation and the regularization of divergent series in theoretical physics and number theory.

The essence of this result can be understood through the application of the Riemann zeta function \( \zeta(s) \), which is defined as \( \zeta(s) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^s} \) for Re(s) > 1. This function can be analytically continued to other values in the complex plane, except for \( s = 1 \) where it has a pole.

The specific value \( \zeta(-1) = -\frac{1}{12} \) is derived by using the analytic continuation of the zeta function to \( s = -1 \), even though this does not represent a sum in the traditional sense. So, when we write:

\[ 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + \cdots = -\frac{1}{12} \]

we're expressing it through this extended notion rather than elementary summation.
